name: copper collector foil production, for Li-ion battery | copper collector foil, for Li-ion battery | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24660/documentation

The dataset represents the production of 1 kg copper foil to be used as current collector for the negative electrode (anode) in Lithium-ion battery. Input materials for pre-treatment, infrastructure and waste are included. ;The dataset has been partly extrapolated from Notter et al. (2010). ;;Reference: Notter, D. A., Gauch, M., Widmer, R., Wager, P., Stamp, A., Zah, R., & Althaus, H. J. (2010). Contribution of Li-ion batteries to the environmental impact of electric vehicles.

The activity starts with copper and chemicals entering the factory.

The activity ends with the production of  copper current collector foil at factory gate,
category: C:Manufacturing/27:Manufacture of electrical equipment/279:Manufacture of other electrical equipment/2790:Manufacture of other electrical equipment

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2010 (year of the publication) and 2020 (year of the dataset)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The specific geography of copper foil production is unknown. This dataset is assumed to be valid for global conditions.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset includes the pre-treatment process of copper foil. The acid cleaning is performed by using sulfuric acid (H2SO4)
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data on chemicals for the pretreatment of aluminium foil are based on Notter et al. (2010). See comment to exchanges.

flow.name: copper collector foil, for Li-ion battery
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/27:Manufacture of electrical equipment/279:Manufacture of other electrical equipment/2790:Manufacture of other electrical equipment

exchanges.description:
Alkaline cleaning processes are based on sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solutions. Some oxide particles and intermetallics, which are insoluble in the alkaline solution, form a ‘smut layer’ which loosely attaches to the aluminium surfaces. As a result, alkaline cleaning must be followed by an acid de-smutting step. 

This is a calculated value, representing the amount of H2SO4 necessary to neutralize NaOH used for the pre-treatment of aluminium foil. Based on stoichiometric calculation, following the reaction  2NaOH + H2SO4 = Na2SO4 + H2O. Therefore 1 kg NaOH is neutralized with 0.62 kg H2SO4. NaOH = 39.99 g/mol; H2SO4 = 99.036 g/mol
